awd_titl_txt: I-Corps Node: For the District of Columbia / Maryland / Virginia (DMV) Region
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is a renewal of the DC I-Corps Node for the midatlantic and southeast region led by the University of Maryland College Park (UMD), in partnership with the George Washington University (GWU), Virginia Tech (VT), and Johns Hopkins (JHU). The DMV Node has a history of utilizing collective university resources, experience in successful technology startup formation, and skilled at entrepreneurial education bringing significant contributions and assets to the National Innovation Network (NIN). The Node will continue to operate as a "regional network", and uses a management model of cooperation and collaboration that sets a standard for the NIN. The Node is also integrating I-Corps concepts into the core curriculum for over 3,000 students of all majors. The Node intends to pursue multiple research initiatives to further improve the program outcomes, and will continue to teach innovators about customer discovery, commercial readiness and the development of sustainable business models. 

This project will continue to contribute a wide range of I-Corps materials, training practices, and curricula built upon its prior activities. These program components will be tailored to suit students, faculty, and other regional innovators. The Node will continue to work closely with Howard University (an I-Corps Site) to bring more I-Corps teams from this leading Historically Black College and University (HBCU). The Node will also collaborate with engineering research groups to provide women entrepreneurs training through I-Corps. Finally, the Node will continue to serve a wide geographic area with a very diverse demographic of innovators and entrepreneurs, including urban and rural populations. The DC Node will improve the success rate of technology transfer and commercialization from world-leading research universities and federal labs by creating new venture or licensing opportunities for program participants.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The DC I-Corps Node initially included the University of Maryland, George Washington University, and Virginia Tech. In the second year of the grant, the Node was the first to propose and attain official NSF approval for Node expansion and recruited Johns Hopkins University to become the first Node with four schools. The Node also recruited and created a strong partnership with Howard University, making it the first HBCU to officially be part of the National Innovation Network.

 Broader Impact

 These five universities worked closely as Node partners throughout the grant, from September 15, 2016, through February 28, 2022. Together, they conducted a wide range of activities to help NSF develop and scale the I-Corps program, methodology and impact throughout the District of Columbia, Maryland, and Virginia (DMV) area, into Pennsylvania and North Carolina, and throughout the country. The University of Pennsylvania, Carnegie Mellon University, and NC State University became close collaborators with the Node.

 During the grant period, the Node served thousands of regional teams and participants, making it the most active and expansive innovation program in the region. The Node built customized I-Corps-based courses for other federal agencies, including NIH, NASA, HHS, DHS, and DOD. The Node co-created the HHS Ignite accelerator program to support the exploration and testing of ideas to modernize government. The Node also served many of the federal research labs in the region, spinning off a self-supporting incubator program called FedTech that matches technology from over 50 partner labs with entrepreneurs to create new startups and jobs. The Node advised and guided an NSF pilot called I-Corps for Learning (I-Corps L) to develop an adaptation of I-Corps to help scale innovations in how STEM is taught and learned, leading to another self-supporting spinout called University Innovation Fellows Teaching and Learning Studio (UIF TLS) that has trained hundreds of faculty from universities worldwide.

 The Node was also tasked by NSF at the outset of the pandemic to develop the first "all virtual" I-Corps curriculum. An unexpected benefit of this transition was a substantial broadening of the reach of the Node and of the NIN, opening access to I-Corps to many more teams from all across the region and all across the country.

In addition, the Node worked with regional economic development agencies in Virginia (CIT), Maryland (TEDCO), and the District of Columbia (Accelerate DC) to support their entrepreneurship and funding programs. To augment these efforts, the Node also developed a regional Mentor network to support I-Corps teams before, during, and after the course.

Finally, the Node pioneered an adaptation of I-Corps-based curriculum that engaged nearly half of the undergraduate students at the University of Maryland across all majors, broadening impact well beyond the traditional STEM fields of most NSF programs.  

 Intellectual Merit

 During the grant period, the Node led the development of the SBIR Bootcamp and SBIR I-Corps programs, which both tailored I-Corps to meet the needs of SBIR companies. This expansion of the I-Corps training represented a significant increase in the number of teams participating in I-Corps activities. In recent years, nearly ninety percent of NSF SBIR Phase I companies participate in the Bootcamp, while nearly twenty five percent participate in the full I-Corps course.

 The Node also trained over one hundred new instructors for Node regional programs and universities, including: American University, Hampton University, Virginia Commonwealth University, the College of William and Mary, George Mason University, the University of Virginia, NC State University, Duke University, the University of North Carolina, the University of Pittsburgh, Carnegie Mellon University, and the University of Pennsylvania.

 All Node partner schools also worked with their respective Technology Transfer Office to integrate I-Corps training into their offices. Many TTOs have embraced the methodology and are actively recruiting teams for training. As a result, I-Corps has become the de-facto front-end of the innovation funnel on most Node campuses.

 The Node also contributed significantly to the body of I-Corps training material and content, and much of it has been standardized across the NIN. For example, the Node was the first to pilot and standardize regional "short courses"  that have been adopted across the NIN.

 Finally, the Node standardized instructor training across all Node institutions and developed its own Train-the-Trainer content for regional instructors and mentors.  

 

 


Last Modified: 05/23/2022
Modified by: Dean Chang
